emphasis.docTitle: Phylogenetic analyses of the subfamily Scarabaeinae ( Coleoptera : Scarabaeidae ) provide new insights into the Mexican Transition Zone theory

subSection.paragraph:
VICTOR MOCTEZUMA 1* , ALEJANDRO ESPINOSA DE LOS MONTEROS 2 & GONZALO HALFFTER 3†
1 Centro Tlaxcala de Biología de la Conducta, Universidad Autónoma de Tlaxcala, km 1.5 Carretera Tlaxcala-Puebla S/N, La Loma Xicohtencatl, Tlaxcala de Xicohténcatl, 90070 Tlaxcala, Mexico.
Ễ abadonjvpm@hotmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4532-0302

subSection.paragraph: Ễ alejandro.espinosa@inecol.mx; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7742-5977

paragraph.emphasis: 3 Emeritous Researcher, Instituto de Ecología, A. C., Carretera antigua a Coatepec 351, El Haya, Xalapa, 91073 Veracruz, Mexico. https://orcid.org/ 0000-0003-1430-7049

subSection.paragraph: Being areas of biotic overlap located between biogeographic regions, transition zones function as natural laboratories. The present study explores the phylogenetic history of the dung beetle subfamily Scarabaeinae , in order to present an evolutionary scenario that allows inference of the biogeographic history of the Mexican Transition Zone (MTZ) and integration of the distributional patterns of its biota. The species sampling included 94 New World taxa (93 species of Scarabaeinae and one species of Aphodiinae ).The phylogenetic relationships of the main clades recovered in our study were supported with PP values ≥ 0.95. Based on the BAYAREALIKE model to reconstruct the ancestral distributional patterns of Scarabaeinae , we inferred a complex scenario with 19 dispersal events, 15 vicariance events, and three extinctions. We suggest that the Ancient Neotropical and Tropical Paleoamerican patterns represent the most likely ancestral distributional patterns for the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ, which probably settle there during the Eocene-Oligocene. The rest of the Scarabaeinae distributional patterns were assembled in subsequent periods. The results suggest that the MTZ had two separate formation stages: a Paleo-MTZ (Eocene-Miocene) and a current MTZ (Pliocene-Anthropocene). We conclude that the evolutionary history as well as the dispersal-vicariance scenario for the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ fits the “out of the tropics” model.
Key words: biogeography , dung beetles , Nearctic region , Neotropical region , out of the tropics model

The first precedents for the MTZ are found in the works of Heilprin (1887) , Dugès (1902) and Darlington (1957). However, it was Halffter (1962) who introduced a hypothesis to explain the geographic distribution of the insects from Mexico and the Americas. In 1964 Halffter reviewed his previous conclusions, and presented a first theory for the history of MTZ. According to this theory ( Halffter 1964 ), the MTZ is a complex area of hybridization and overlap between the Nearctic and Neotropical regions, which extends from the southeastern United States to the Nicaraguan lowlands ( Fig. 1 ). Since then, until recent years, the theory of the MTZ has been subsequently broadened ( Halffter 1978 , 1987 , 2017, 2019;
Halffter et al . 1995
, 2008 , 2019; Moctezuma & Halffter 2019 ). The most complete formal presentation of the theory of the MTZ is found in the works of
Morrone (2015 b
, 2019, 2020) and Halffter & Morrone (2017) , who compiled the ideas raised around Halffter’s initial proposal.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 1. Mexican Transition Zone ( sensu Halffter 1964 ). A complex geographic space, in which the overlap of the Nearctic and Neotropical biota occurred. A) Digital elevation model. B) Main orographic systems.

subSection.paragraph: The distributional patterns in the MTZ have been characterized based on four elements: 1) the biogeographic origin [which in a broad sense can be Neotropical ( i.e. , southern) or Holarctic ( i.e. , northern)]; 2) the hypothetical age of dispersal towards the MTZ; 3) the geographic configuration of the MTZ when the phyletic lineages dispersed; and 4) the current distribution and ecological requirements of the taxa (Halffter 2017; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). As a consequence, the lineages of insects of the MTZ that hypothetically originated from South American ancestors have been classified into four distributional patterns: Mexican Plateau, Mountain Mesoamerican, Neotropical Baja Californian and Typical Neotropical ( Halffter & Morrone 2017 ; Moctezuma & Halffter 2019 ; Morrone 2020). Moreover, the lineages of insects that radiated in the Old World and dispersed through North America to the MTZ are included within the Paleoamerican (with six sub-patterns, later described) and Nearctic distributional patterns ( Halffter & Morrone 2017 ; Morrone 2020).

We used sequences of 94 taxa of the subfamily Scarabaeinae ( Table 1 ). Most of the taxa selected are distributed in the MTZ. Thirty-three taxa were collected in the field and sequenced de novo for this study (accession numbers under request). The rest of the taxa were selected according to the availability of database sequences (GenBank).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Species and markers used in this study.

heading.emphasis: DNA extraction, PCR, and sequencing techniques

subSection.paragraph: The PCRs were run in a final reaction volume of 25 µl: 1 µl DNA (20–40 ng), 4 µl 5X Buffer, 2 µl MgCl2 (25 mM), 2.5 µl dNTPs (8 lM), 0.25 µl BSA, 0.8 µl of each primer (10 µM), 0.2 µl Taq polymerase (5 U/ µl) and 13.35 µl ddH2O. PCR cycling conditions were as follows: initial denaturing at 94 °C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles at 94 °C for 1 min for denaturing, 50 °C for 1 min for annealing, and 70 °C for 2 min for extension, finishing with a final extension step at 72 °C for 5 min. Variations of this protocol were used for problematic samples: the best yield for 16S was obtained with 35 cycles, whereas the optimal annealing for ITS 2 was performed at 53 °C. PCR products were visualized on 1% agarose gels stained with ethidium bromide and purified with the QIAquick kit (QIAGEN). PCR purifications were sequenced abroad by Macrogen Inc. (Seoul, South Korea).

We dated the phylogeny using the software BEAST v1.10.2 ( Drummond et al. 2012 ), with the ‘Uncorrelated relaxed clock’ model. The BI topology inferred from the combined data set was used as a prior tree. For this study, the phylogeny was calibrated using the fossil record, considering 53 Myr as the minimum age for the whole subfamily
Scarabaeinae (Tarasov et al . 2016)
. A Bayesian factor test showed that the different molecular markers could be concatenated in a single matrix, but declared as independent partitions. Thus, the nucleotide substitution models were unlinked, as were the parameters used as priors for each locus. Models and parameters were those indicated by jMODELTEST. The Yule process was used to estimate the speciation tree model. The MCMC were run for 10 million generations, with sampling trees and parameters every 1000 generations. The analysis consisted of 10 independent runs to ensure that all parameters achieve statistical stationarity. The program TRACER v1.6 (
Rambaut et al . 2014
) was used for assessing the stationarity of the MCMC, effective sample sizes (ESSs> 200) and the 95% highest posterior density for interval spanning. The resulting trees and parameters from each run were combined using LogCombiner v1.8.2, applying a 25% burn-in of the initial data. The nodes evaluated for the final tree were those with PP value> 0.9.

An optimization analysis to infer the dispersal and vicariance events that occurred during the evolutionary history of the Scarabaeinae in the MTZ was implemented in the software RASP 4 (
Yu et al . 2020
). To avoid the bias expected from the use of the outgroup, the species
O. indutilis
was removed from the input trees. The ancestral state of each node was reconstructed in the condensed tree by using 5000 randomly selected trees from the remaining 60003 trees inferred after the 25% burn in in BEAST. The best-fit model for the ancestral area reconstruction was implemented with BioGeoBEARS ( Matzke 2013a , 2013b , 2014 ). A highest AICc_wt value of 223.3 was retrieved from the BAYAREALIKE model. We assigned each taxon to the distributional patterns according to the MTZ theory. The reason to code the species with their distributional patterns and not with their individual distributional areas, is that these patterns can be considered as a reliable proxy for the current distributional areas of the cenocrons that assembled in the MTZ ( Morrone 2015b , 2020; Halffter 2017, 2019; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). We must stress the fact that the objective of this study is to assess the general geographic patterns proposed by the theory of the MTZ for the biotic assemblages ( i.e. , cenocrons), instead of the distribution of individual species. Unfortunately, in this study taxa from the Neotropical Baja Californian, Nearctic, Relict Paleoamerican and Paleoamerican Baja Californian cenocrons were omitted because we were unable to obtain sequences of their representative species. So far, the use of analytical methods to evaluate the theory of the MTZ, as well as our knowledge of the cenocrons that occur in the New World is still incipient. Consequently, the results and conclusions derived from this study are subjected to the current definition of the accepted cenocrons implemented here.

The length of the alignment obtained with the four loci was 3156 base pairs ( ITS 2 = 736 bp, 16S = 539 bp, COI = 1261 bp and COII = 620 bp). The de novo sequences were deposited in GenBank ( Table 1 , accession numbers under request). The best-fit models of nucleotide substitution were: GTR (nst=6) + Inv (0.699) for ITS 2, TVM (nst=6) + Inv (0.259) + Gamma (0.386) for 16S, GTR (nst=6) + Inv (0.412) + Gamma (0.375) for COI, and TrN (nst=6) + Inv (0.341) + Gamma (0.277) for COII . Phylogenetic relationships of major clades represented in our study are supported with PP values ≥ 0.95 ( Fig. 2 ).

It is important to make clear that the temporal scenario recovered here is mainly based on the dates inferred for the nodes of the phylogenetic tree. These nodes represent the splitting events of the lineages and not necessarily the exact time at which the distributional patterns were consolidated. Nonetheless, the dates are the average time value associated with a statistical variance that implies temporal uncertainty. The historical scenario presented here thus should be scrutinized when more accurate methods for estimating time are available. The inferred chronogram ( Fig. 2 ) suggests that the events of diversification that lead to the radiation of the lineages currently distributed at the MTZ occurred between 54 and 18 Myr ago. The tribe Phanaeini began its diversification around 23.4 Myr ago (95% confidence limits 18.4–28.5 Myr). Another important evolutionary event was the radiation of the genus
Onthophagus Latreille, 1802
, which began approximately 26.7 Myr ago (95% confidence limits 22.6–31 Myr). The radiation events of other important genera began almost simultaneously, as was the case of
Copris Geoffroy, 1762
(26.7 Myr; 95% confidence limits 17.4–36.4 Myr),
Uroxys Westwood, 1842
(24.2 Myr; 95% confidence limits 16.6–31.8 Myr) and
Eurysternus Dalman, 1824
(28.7 Myr; 95% confidence limits 21.6–35.1 Myr). The most recent radiation events correspond to
Dichotomius Hope, 1838
(19.8 Myr; 95% confidence limits 11.6–29 Myr),
Canthidium Erichson, 1847
(18.2 Myr; 95% confidence limits 11.2–25.6 Myr) and
Ateuchus Weber, 1801
(15.3 Myr; 95% confidence limits 10.3–21.2 Myr).

heading.emphasis: Reconstruction of ancestral stages and biogeographic scenario

subSection.paragraph:
The BAYAREALIKE model suggests a scenario comprising multiple dispersal and diversification events of the Scarabaeinae that promoted the assembly of the distributional patterns in the MTZ. The analysis infers 19 events of dispersal, 15 events of vicariance and 3 extinctions ( Fig. 3 ). The Typical Neotropical distribution scored the greatest diversification and the highest number of dispersal events ( Tables 2–3 ). During the Oligocene-Pleistocene, multiple speciation events were presented for genera such as
Ateuchus ,
Canthon Hoffmannsegg, 1817
,
Canthidium , Dichotomius , Eurysternus ,
Phanaeus MacLeay, 1819
,
Scatimus Erichson, 1847
, and
Uroxys
. The theory of the MTZ considers that the ancestors of those taxa were part of the Typical Neotropical distribution. In particular, the Typical Neotropical distribution of the genus
Phanaeus
yielded to the lineages with Mexican Plateau distribution during the Miocene. The ancestor of the taxa that follow the Mexican Plateau distribution appeared during the Miocene ( i.e. ,
P. yecoraensis Edmonds, 2004
+
P. vindex MacLeay, 1819
+
P. igneus MacLeay, 1819
+
P. furiosus Bates, 1887
+
P. nimrod Harold, 1863
+
P. texensis Edmonds, 1994
+
P. quadridens (Say, 1835))
. At the end of the Miocene, the taxa with a Mexican Plateau distribution diversified and gave origin to the lineage
P. endymion Harold, 1863
+
P. pyrois Bates, 1887
. Also, during the Miocene the Mountain Mesoamerican distribution was integrated by three different speciation events corresponding to the genera
Eurysternus
(
E. magnus Castelnau, 1840
),
Phanaeus
(
P. amethystinus Harold, 1863
+
P. guatemalensis Harold, 1871
) and
Ontherus
(
O. mexicanus Harold, 1868
), and an additional event during the early Pliocene (
A. colossus Moctezuma, Sánchez-Huerta & Halffter, 2018
).

The ancestors of the Paleoamerican genera
Copris
and
Onthophagus
appeared in the MTZ during the Oligocene. In the genus
Copris
, the ancestors of the Mesoamerican Paleoamerican (
C. chimalapensis Mora-Aguilar & Delgado, 2015
) and Mountain Paleoamerican (
C. armatus Harold, 1869
) distributions originated during the Miocene. The Tropical Paleoamerican distribution appeared as an ancestral stage in the genus
Onthophagus
from which the rest of the Paleoamerican distributions originated. In this genus, the Mesoamerican Paleoamerican distribution appeared during the Miocene as a result of a cladogenesis event (
O. cyanellus Bates, 1887
), while the Mountain Paleoamerican distribution arose from two different cladogenesis events (
O. orizabensis Moctezuma, Joaqui & Sánchez-Huerta, 2019
and
O. halffteri Zunino, 1981
) during the same period of time. The Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican distribution was the result of three independent events, two during the Miocene (
O. pennsylvanicus Harold, 1871
+
O. etlaensis Kohlmann, Escobar-Hernández & Arriaga-Jiménez, 2019
;
O. orpheus (Panzer, 1794)
+
O. anthracinus Harold, 1873
+
O. hecate (Panzer, 1794))
and one during the Plio-Pleistocene (
O. nitidior Bates, 1887
).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 3. Ancestral state reconstruction of the distributional patterns (BAYAREALIKE), plotted on a condensed tree assembled from 5000 random trees. The numbers indicate the marginal probability for each hypothetical ancestral range: only values above 80% are shown. Taxa previously considered as part of the Typical Neotropical (many of them proposed herein as the Ancient Neotropical distributional pattern) presented the greatest number of events of speciation and dispersal. A) Mesoamerican Paleoamerican, B) Mexican Plateau, C) Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican, D) Mountain Mesoamerican, E) Typical Neotropical, F) Tropical Paleoamerican, G) Mountain Paleoamerican.

TABLE 3. Speciation within distributional patterns (BAYAREALIKE).
Distributional pattern
B Mexican Plateau
C Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican
D Mountain Mesoamerican
E Typical Neotropical
G Tropical Paleoamerican

subSection.paragraph:
To better understand the evolutionary history and biogeographic processes that have shaped the diversity of Scarabaeinae , it would be desirable to increase the representation of geographic areas in future phylogenetic analyses. Our study is based on a regional subset of New World taxa that complements the global understanding of complex distributional patterns ( i.e. , African Scarabaeinae : Sole & Scholtz 2010 and
Mlambo et al . 2015
, and Australasian fauna:
Gunter et al . 2018
). The genera
Onthophagus
, which is distributed in all continental-land masses (except for the Antarctica) and several islands (
Breeschoten et al . 2016
), and
Copris
, which mainly occurs in Africa-Eurasia and the New World ( Matthews 1961 ), represent two particular complex cases. These genera are widely distributed and highly diversified, which makes difficult adequately represent them in phylogenetic studies.

The phylogenetic reconstruction of the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ allowed us to explore the integration of the different distributional patterns in an evolutionary scenario. In general terms, the scenarios of dispersal and diversification proposed by previous authors ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 , 1978 , 1987 , 2017;
Halffter et al ., 1995
, 2008 , 2019; Morrone, 2015b ) are not completely consistent with the reconstruction of ancestral stages presented in our study. According to our phylogenetic hypothesis, the only distributional patterns that completely agree with the temporal scenario as suggested by the previous literature are the Mountain Mesoamerican and Mesoamerican Paleoamerican, which appeared during the Miocene ( Halffter 1978 , 1987 ;
Halffter et al . 2019
). The former includes lineages of Neotropical origin (e. g.,
A. colossus
,
P. amethystinus
+
P. guatemalensis
,
E. magnus
,
O. mexicanus
), while the latter corresponds to lineages of Holarctic origin (such as
O. cyanellus
).

Halffter (1964) proposed that the dispersal of the Neotropical entomofauna towards the Mexican Plateau began prior to the elevation of this region, during the upper Cretaceous and early Eocene. This entomofauna evolved into endemic lineages of the southern United States of America, northern Mexico, the Balsas basin and the highlands of Chiapas and Guatemala ( Halffter 1964 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). In our study, the Mexican Plateau distribution corresponds to the
Phanaeus
clade. Our results suggest that this clade is South American in origin and that it dispersed towards the Mexican Plateau during the Miocene, in a period more recent than had been previously hypothesized ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 ). A previous study agrees with this result by suggesting that the Mexican Plateau elements, such as the species of the subgenus
Boreocanthon Halffter, 1958
and
Canthon imitator Brown, 1946
diversified during the Miocene, along together with the subgenus
Bajacanthon Halffter, 2022
(
Halffter et al . 2022
), which follows the Neotropical Baja Californian pattern and was hypothesized to have appeared during the Miocene ( Moctezuma & Halffter 2019 ). Therefore, we suggest that the elevation of the Mexican Plateau did not by itself represented a geographic barrier that prevented the dispersal of Neotropical elements, but rather the dispersal of these taxa towards the Mexican Plateau was probably impeded by the orogeny of the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt during the Plio-Pleistocene (
Nieto-Samaniego et al . 2007
;
Ferrari et al . 2012
,
Mastretta-Yanes et al . 2015
).

It is hypothesized that the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern represents a relatively recent dispersal event towards the MTZ and subsequent diversification, which took place together with the GABI during the Plio-Pleistocene ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). However, our results suggest that taxa previously considered as part of the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern diversified from multiple events of dispersal, which took place from the Oligocene to the Plio-Pleistocene.

According to our temporal scenario, two diversification events during the Plio-Pleistocene within the genus
Eurysternus
fit the Typical Neotropical pattern (
E. mexicanus Harold, 1869
+
E. obliteratus Génier, 2009
; and
E. foedus Guérin-Méneville, 1830
+
E. velutinus Bates, 1887
). In addition, the speciation events that resulted in
A. chrysopygus Bates, 1887
,
C. pluto (Harold, 1863)
,
C. corythus (Harold, 1863)
,
P. demon Castelnau, 1840
, and
D. amplicollis Harold, 1869
also support the Plio-Pleistocene diversification of the Typical Neotropical pattern ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). Finally,
Nolasco-Soto et al . (2017
, 2023 ) have suggested that the roller dung beetle
Canthon cyanellus LeConte, 1859
is a complex of cryptic species that probably diversified during the Pleistocene, representing another lineage that adequately describes this Typical Neotropical distributional pattern.

Phanaeus endymion
+
P. pyrois
are species endemic to the tropical rainforests at the MTZ (Moctezuma & Halffter, 2021), and were subject to a Pleistocene speciation event consistent with the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern. It would be expected that the hypothetical ancestors of Typical Neotropical lineages were Neotropical elements of South American origin ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). Our results, however, suggest that
P. endymion
+
P. pyrois
originated from an ancestor that followed the Mexican Plateau distributional pattern. This agrees with the phylogenetic hypothesis presented by Gillett & Toussaint (2020) , where
P. endymion
and related species were nested within a clade that includes species that inhabit the Mexican Plateau. As a consequence, we propose herein that the Typical Neotropical pattern not only is integrated by Scarabaeinae lineages with ancestors that dispersed from South America during the Plio-Pleistocene, but some lineages originated from dispersal events of ancestors that previously inhabited the Mexican Plateau.

heading.emphasis: The Oligocene-Miocene Neotropical diversification and a new distributional pattern

subSection.paragraph:
Some genera that were classified in previous studies as Typical Neotropical probably dispersed towards the MTZ during the Oligocene (e.g.,
Canthon
,
Deltochilum
,
Eurysternus
,
Scatimus
and
Uroxys
). The dispersal of this group of taxa might be explained by the presence of the proto-Antilles in the Caribbean Sea during the Eocene-Oligocene that allowed the exchange of fauna between North and South America (
Agnolin et al . 2019
; Crews & Esposito 2020 ). Other Neotropical taxa included in our study (
Ateuchus , Canthidium ,
Coprophanaeus Olsoufieff, 1924
,
Dichotomius , Phanaeus
and
Sulcophanaeus Olsoufieff, 1924
) probably dispersed to the MTZ and diversified during the Miocene. The Panama Seaway Closure could have favored the dispersal of these genera. Recent studies suggest that this event started to consolidate during the mid-Miocene, facilitating the dispersal of different groups of organisms in periods prior to the GABI (
Montes et al . 2015
; Jaramillo 2018 , 2019 ). Even if the Panamanian Land Bridge formed around 3 Myr ago (
O’Dea et al . 2016
), the Neotropical dung beetles might have dispersed to the MTZ from northern South America by an “island hopper” process using the Central American Volcanic Arc islands formed during the Oligocene-Miocene.
Magalhaes et al . (2023)
suggest that the faunal interchange between South and Central America started around 30 Myr ago, and this interchange intensified at least 20 Myr ago for the Neotropical spider genus
Micrathena Sundevall, 1833
. Our results are consistent with those presented by
Halffter et al . (2022)
, who suggested that some Neotropical Deltochilini lineages from the MTZ, such as
C. indigaceus LeConte, 1866
and
Pseudocanthon perplexus (LeConte, 1847)
, appeared during the Miocene-Pliocene as a result of different cladogenetic and dispersal events.

The Neotropical elements that dispersed to the MTZ during the Miocene-Oligocene do not fit with the Typical Neotropical distributional pattern as currently defined. In order to separate these Neotropical elements that represent the oldest dispersal and diversification events in the MTZ, we propose a new distributional pattern: the Ancient Neotropical. This distributional pattern includes extant species and lineages ( i.e. ,
C. pseudopuncticolle
+
C. ardens
+
C. guanacaste
,
D. satanas
+
D. yucatanus
+
D. colonicus
,
E. hamaticollis
+
E. caribaeus
+
E. plebejus
+
E. angustulus
), which diversified during the Miocene, and the hypothetical Neotropical ancestors that appeared during the Oligocene-Miocene. In this regard, the Ancient Neotropical represents the ancestral distributional pattern of South American origin in the MTZ, which gave rise to the rest of the Neotropical distributional patterns ( i.e. , Mexican Plateau, Mountain Mesoamerican, Baja Californian, and Typical Neotropical).

Some examples of the close phylogenetic relationship between the Neotropical and African Scarabaeinae are represented by
Eurysternus
(sister group of the clade
Epactoides Olsoufieff, 1947
+
Ochicanthon
Vaz-de-Mello, 2003; Tarasov & Dimitrov 2016 ),
Streblopus Van Lansberge, 1874
(closely related to
Circellium Latreille, 1825
and Scarabaeini ; Cupello et al . 2020),
Gromphas Brullé, 1838
(whose phylogenetic placement within Phanaeini or Onitini is disputed; Gillett & Toussaint 2020 ; Schoolmeesters 2023 ), and Deltochilini (which were placed as the sister group of a clade that contains the tribes Eurysternini, Gymnopleurini, Oniticellini, Onitini, Onthophagini and Sisyphini; Tarasov & Dimitrov 2016 ). The phylogenetic relationships and putative ancestry of the Neotropical genera
Uroxys Westwood, 1842
and
Bdelyropsis Pereira, Vulcano & Martínez, 1960
represent a particularly enigmatic case. Tarasov & Dimitrov (2016) suggested that both are nested within the Australasian endemic genera. Also, Tarasov & Génier (2015) indicated that
Uroxys
and
Bdelyropsis
are sister to other Neotropical taxa; while
Gunter et al . (2018)
proposed that those genera conform the sister group of the African
Pedaria Laporte, 1832
and the Australian
Boletoscapter Matthews, 1974
.

Further studies are needed to understand if the morphological affinities of
Uroxys
and
Bdelyropsis
with different New World genera ( Tarasov & Génier 2015 ) are a consequence of convergent evolution. The phylogenetic relationships proposed by Tarasov & Dimitrov (2016) indicate an Australasian ancestry for both genera; therefore, they would not be consistent with the Ancient Neotropical pattern as proposed herein. Furthermore,
Gunter et al . (2018)
suggested a likely Gondwanan origin for these Neotropical genera, which is not consistent with our results. As an alternative explanation, the sister relationship of
Uroxys
,
Bdelyropsis
,
Pedaria
, and
Boletoscapter
recovered by
Gunter et al . (2018)
may be the result of a transoceanic dispersal of closely related African ancestors that gave rise to the Neotropical and Australian genera, which make plausible our hypothesis of the Ancient Neotropical distributional pattern with an Afrotropical ancestry.

Previous authors have suggested that the Paleoamerican distribution corresponds to Holarctic taxa that dispersed towards North America during the upper Cretaceous to the Paleocene ( Halffter 1964 ; Morrone 2015b ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). Our results suggest that the Paleoamerican distribution originated during the late Oligocene, which is consistent with a previous study that suggests that the dispersal of
Onthophagus
towards the New World took place since the late Oligocene until early Miocene (
Breeschoten et al . 2016
). According to
Breeschoten et al . (2016)
, the New World
Onthophagus
probably arose in a single cladogenetic event from an Australian lineage that subsequently dispersed towards North America via Beringia. It appears that a land bridge connected western North America with eastern Asia on multiple occasions, from the mid-Cretaceous to the Pliocene, enabling biotic exchange between both continental masses (
Sanmartín et al . 2001
;
Gou et al . 2012
;
Oliveros et al . 2019
). This makes plausible the phylogenetic hypotheses of
Breeschoten et al . (2016)
and that presented by our study.

Our phylogenetic hypothesis suggests that the Tropical Paleoamerican represents the ancestral distribution of the New World
Onthophagus
, from which originated the rest of the Paleoamerican elements. Two species of New World
Onthophagus
were recently referred to as Typical Neotropical (
Moctezuma et al . 2020b
), but this was a mistake because both species must be considered as Tropical Paleoamerican. Previous authors (
Kohlmann et al . 2019
; Kohlmann-Cuesta 2022 ) have suggested that the term “Boreotropical distribution” should substitute that of Tropical Paleoamerican distribution, since they considered it a more complete and soundly based concept. The hypothesis of Boreotropical distribution suggests that a continuous strip of vegetation extended over the entire Northern hemisphere during the early Cenozoic, dispersing from Asia to North America through Beringia ( Wolfe 1978 ;
Sanmartín et al . 2001
). The subsequent climatic conditions of the terminal Eocene event caused the demise of the Boreotropical forest, as well as the subsequent isolation and vicariance of the organisms that inhabited this forest ( Wolfe 1978 ). In this way, a lineage that has its current center of diversity in tropical North America and appears in the fossil record during the early Paleocene, has a high probability of having sister groups in the Paleotropics and derived relatives in South America ( Lavin & Luckow 1993 ).

However, the hypothesis of Boreotropical distribution is not consistent with the evolutionary history of the New World
Onthophagus
, taking into consideration the evidence provided by our results and those of previous studies: 1) As stated above, our phylogenetic hypothesis and that of
Breeschoten et al . (2016)
suggest the appearance of the New World
Onthophagus
during the late Oligocene, in a period much later than the dispersal and demise of the Boreotropical forest ( Wolfe 1978 ;
Sanmartín et al . 2001
). Moreover, paleoenvironmental reconstructions suggest the existence of tropical forests in the MTZ and northern South America during the Oligocene ( Solórzano-Kraemer 2007 ; Jaramillo 2019 ;
Carvalho et al . 2021
), while this type of forest constitutes a suitable habitat for the Tropical Paleoamerican
Onthophagus ( Zunino & Halffter 1997 )
. 2) No fossil evidence is known that indicates the occurrence of
Onthophagus
in North America during the early Tertiary. The only known fossils to date are traced back to the Pleistocene (Tarasov et al . 2016;
Tello et al . 2021a
, 2021b ). 3) The hypothetical sister group of the New World
Onthophagus
is found outside of the Paleotropics, in Australia (
Breeschoten et al . 2016
). 4) The center of diversity of the Tropical Paleoamerican
Onthophagus
is found in the tropical rainforests of Central America and northern South America ( Zunino & Halffter 1997 ; Kohlmann & Solís 2001 ), not in tropical North America (
Kohlmann et al . 2019
). 5) Finally, Kohlmann-Cuesta (2022) supported his conclusions with the temporal calibrations provided by
Gunter et al . (2016)
and Schwery & O’Meara (2021) ; however, that is not reliable due to the fact that misidentified fossils were used for such calibrations. As a consequence, we can disregard the proposal by
Kohlmann et al . (2019)
and Kohlmann-Cuesta (2022) , and retain the term Tropical Paleoamerican based on the evidence presented here.

The appearance of the Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican distribution was expected to be during the upper Cretaceous to early Cenozoic, prior to the elevation of the Mexican Plateau ( Halffter 1962 , 1964 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). Our results suggest that some Paleoamerican taxa dispersed towards the Mexican Plateau during the Miocene, while others did so during the Pleistocene. In either case, the Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican distribution arose from ancestors of Tropical Paleoamerican distribution. We can therefore suggest that the entomofauna of the Mexican Plateau were formed by at least two events of dispersal. The first event took place prior to completion of the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt (
Ferrari et al . 2012
,
Mastretta-Yanes et al . 2015
), when the Holarctic and Neotropical Scarabaeinae that inhabited the tropical lowlands of the MTZ dispersed freely towards the Mexican Plateau. It is possible to consider this dispersal event as the most important in terms of the formation of the entomofauna of the Mexican Plateau, since the lineages involved became isolated by the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt and subsequently dispersed to the southern United States of America, where they diversified ( Zunino & Halffter 1997 ; Halffter & Morrone 2017 ; Edmonds 1994 ). The second event of dispersal occurred after the formation of the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt, during the Pleistocene. Given that only one species ( i.e. ,
O. nitidior
) was assigned to this event, we suggest that it involved a very limited number of lineages of Scarabaeinae that had the capacity to overcome the geographic barrier represented by the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt.

heading.emphasis: The paleogeographic scenario and formation of the MTZ

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 4. Paleographical maps of North America (modified from Halffter & Morrone 2017 ), routes of dispersal (arrows) and areas of diversification (polygons) of the distributional patterns of the MTZ. Oligocene: the Paleo-MTZ forms with the dispersal of the tropical septentrional (Tropical Paleoamerican, red arrows) and South American (Ancient Neotropical, yellow arrows) taxa. Miocene: the Mexican Plateau (A, blue area), Mountain Paleoamerican (B, green area) and Mesoamerican (C, pink area) distributional patterns originated and diversified. During this period, the Ancient Neotropical and Tropical Paleoamerican taxa diversified in South America (D), and dispersed once again towards the Paleo-MTZ (yellow and red arrows). The Mountain Paleoamerican taxa dispersed towards the Sierra Madre del Sur (green arrow). The Baja Californian Paleoamerican and Neotropical Baja Californian distributional patterns dispersed to the southern Baja California Peninsula. Pliocene: The current MTZ begins with the consolidation of the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt and sinking of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. The taxa of Mexican Plateau (A, blue arrow) and Mountain Paleoamerican (B, green arrow) taxa dispersed towards Central America, while the Mesoamerican taxa dispersed towards Mexico and northern South America (C, pink arrow). Central America becomes the main route for the Typical Neotropical and Ancient Neotropical taxa that dispersed from South America to the MTZ (D, red and yellow arrows). The biota of southern Baja California is isolated by the formation of the Gulf of California. Pleistocene: the entomofauna of the MTZ reached their current configuration, characterized by a strong overlap of taxa with different biogeographic histories.

subSection.paragraph:
During the Pleistocene, the connection between northern Asia and North America was lost (
Sanmartín et al . 2001
). In this period, the mountains of the MTZ had already reached their current orographic configuration, forming geographic barriers that prevented the dispersal of tropical elements and those of the Mexican Plateau (
Ferrari et al . 2012
;
Mastretta-Yanes et al . 2015
; Halffter & Morrone 2010). The Isthmus of Tehuantepec reached its current formation, restricting the dispersal of Holarctic taxa (such as the
O. chevrolati
species group) from the temperate mountains and the Mexican Plateau towards the south ( Halffter & Morrone 2017 ). This stage saw the demise of the mammalian megafauna and an increase in the aridity of the MTZ, which probably promoted the extinction of numerous species of Scarabaeinae (e.g.,
Copris pristinus Pierce, 1946
;
Onthophagus everestae Pierce, 1946
;
Phanaeus labreae (Pierce, 1946))
and reduced the species richness of their communities (
Miller et al . 1981
; Miller 1983 ; Edmonds 1994 ; Faith & Surovell 2009 ; Favila 2012 ). Thanks to their long evolutionary history in tropical environments, the Scarabaeinae dung beetles showed many trophic adaptations in the Neotropics, such as saprophagy, necrophagy and mycophagy, which allowed the persistence of highly diverse communities despite the loss of the mammalian megafauna ( Halffter & Matthews 1966 ; Cano 1998 ; Cook 1998 ;
Larsen et al . 2006
, Halffter & Halffter 2009 ;
Rodrigues-Aquino et al . 2018
; Gillett & Toussaint 2020 ).

We address the theory of the MTZ and its distributional patterns with the phylogenetic reconstruction of a group of dung beetles, the subfamily Scarabaeinae . This phylogenetic hypothesis is the most complete to date for the MTZ Scarabaeinae . The Ancient Neotropical and Tropical Paleoamerican represented the ancestral distributional patters in our phylogenetic hypothesis. As a consequence, we suggest that the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ diversified in tropical environments from a very early stage of their evolutionary history (Eocene-Oligocene). The Scarabaeinae subsequently dispersed towards extratropical environments during the Miocene in which the greatest process of adaptive radiation took place. This period saw the rise of the rest of the distribution patterns of the MTZ (Mountain Paleoamerican, Mountain Mesoamerican, Mesoamerican Paleoamerican, Mexican Plateau and Mexican Plateau Paleoamerican).

We also suggest that the MTZ formed in two different stages: the Paleo-MTZ and the current MTZ. The Paleo-MTZ occurred between the Eocene and Miocene, when the main orographic systems of the region began or consolidated their formation, and all of the distributional patterns appeared. In the period of the current MTZ (from the Pliocene to the Anthropocene), all the orographic systems reached their current configuration, giving rise to the main biogeographic barriers: the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt for the biota of tropical affinity and the Isthmus of Tehuantepec for the biota of temperate environments. The evolutionary history of the Scarabaeinae of the MTZ fits the “out of the tropics” model, in which taxa originated mainly in the tropics and expanded towards extratropical environments without losing their initial tropical distributions, while species movement was higher from the tropics to the extratropical areas (
Jablonski et al . 2006
; Arita & Vázquez-Domínguez 2008 ).
